subject: Self Care
title: Screen Time and the Brain
description: A quick, practical guide to Screen Time and the Brain.

hook.text: The average adult spends over seven hours daily on screens. That's more than 100 days per year staring at glass.

buildup.text: Excessive screen time shrinks gray matter in areas responsible for planning, organizing, and impulse control.

discovery.text: It's not screens themselves that harm â€” it's the passive, fragmented consumption that rewires attention circuits.

twist.text: Active screen use â€” creating, learning, connecting meaningfully â€” doesn't cause the same damage as passive scrolling.

climax.text: Audit your screen time. Separate active from passive use. Reduce passive. Protect active. The brain will thank you.

punchline.text: Not all screen time is equal. Passive scrolling is the real threat.

quiz.question: What type of screen use is most harmful to the brain?
options: Passive, fragmented consumption like mindless scrolling
Active creation and learning on screens
